ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual discussion section once a week
section in zoom seminar format once/week for 50 minutes & live Q&A sessions once/week.

Weekly discussion section led by TA.
Live virtual optional weekly Q&A session.
Recorded lecture every week along with a weekly section and live virtual Question & Answer section.
pre-recorded lecture, live Q&A

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more about the history of the Atlantic slave trade
larger understanding of slavery's development than just the US. Origins of Atlantic Slavery and its evolution.

I developed my ability to closely analyze primary sources and connect them to a larger historical trend.
I also learned about the history of atpantic slavery--how it developed, how it changed, how it ended. We talked about slavery on both sides of the atlantic and across many different nations and empires.
I learned how to connect various time periods together and how to write a college level essay.
In addition to everything I learned about the Rise and fall of Atlantic slavery, I gained so many amazing insights about my writing skills. My writing is a lot better now!
comprehensive understanding of all of the factors at play in the transatlantic slave trade

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength was the readings, they were pretty interesting. A weakness were the lectures, they were pretty slow in terms of pace so it was hard to maintain attention, since it was basically a re-reading of a prepared script. Sometimes the lectures also didn't seem to connect well with the readings for the week and the jumps weren't well connected or transitioned.

many intro courses are difficult to be made extensively exciting, and COVID made that even more difficult. Nonetheless, if you do the readings and are willing to put in work there's a well of knowledge to be gathered.

I thought the readings and lectures were relevant and interesting. The primary sources were excellent and super helpful.
I thought lecture wasn't the most engaging, especially since it was recorded not live.
This course works really well in a recorded format. The professor's lecturing style is fast and a little hard to take notes on without the ability to pause a video.
The ability to craft an argument is the overall improvement seen in this course.

This course required a tremendous amount of focus because we covered so many years of African slavery in such a short amount of time but this course was well put together so this aspect was not too hard to accomplish.
Phenomenally detailed and interesting lectures, average amount of reading but the discussions sections did a nice job of tying everything together

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion sections were good because since they were small there was active engagement and discussion. But the lectures could be improved and be more lively and more slideshows to go along with the lecture.

For this type of course, I think it was structured as best I could imagine. Only qualm I really had was having a paper due the day after our only break of the semester which made enjoying the days off much more difficult.

Posting recorded lectures was a big change. It made the lectures less engaging.
The live Q&A session made up for that somewhat.

Because of COVID, the lectures were recorded with a weekly live Q&A. The recorded lectures were really helpful for my note-taking, since the professor's style consists of him reciting without very many pauses and without much aid from the power point. There were some technical difficulties which could be improved--several times the power point was not included in the lecture recording.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think you get a nice overview of the history of slavery, and you get to read some really interesting sources.

if you're a history buff or an AFAM/AFST major: yes. It isn't a course I'd really say "no" to, but if you don't fit any of the mentioned descriptions I can imagine you enjoying other courses much more.
Yes. I thought it was an interesting class and i developed my writing skills a lot.
Yes, I would. It's an important topic and a well structured class. However, your experience can really be shaped by who your TA is.
Yes because this course teaches a lot of history that is pertinent to understanding African American history now.
Yes. For both the in depth knowledge of slaverys history and improved writing skills
Absolutely, this should probably be a required course for all undergraduates frankly
